I don't know anything about this offhand, but I just got thinking about how dragonflies have four wings, and I started to wonder what the extent of their agility would actually be. Since they can control all four wings independently—both respecting motion in one direction (flapping up and down), as well as angle in the opposite direction (rotation forwards/backwards)—wouldn't it be possible for them to use two wings to rotate upon one axis, while using the other two wings to simultaneously rotate upon a second axis; in so doing, changing their orientation with respect to the third axis, upon which they're NOT rotating?

In other words, I'm assuming that it would at least be possible in theory, if not actually possible, for a dragonfly to make a full 360 degree rotation either forwards or backwards (front flip/backflip), while also making a full 360 degree rotation either clockwise or counterclockwise (roll over in either direction), and in so doing, face 180 degrees opposite their original direction—by default, and literally without ever actually turning around.

I loved catching dragonflies when I was a child. Some species like the Common Green Darner do bite (and they bite hard) when handled by their abdomen while others either don't bite as hard or don't bite at all. The Flame Skimmer, for instance, doesn't bite at all when caught. It was also easy for me to catch. I just swing my hand and grab it as it rests on a twig and starting to take off.

Others, like the Common Green Darner and the Blue-Eyed Darner, are harder to catch. Virtually impossible for anyone to catch one of these Darners as it rests on a branch or a twig. And they spend most of their waking time gliding in the air. So, for that reason, I used a tennis racket to catch these Darners. I give them a soft whack as they glide in the air. Even after getting whacked, these Darners could still bite.

Insects don't have lungs, instead they have holes all over their body called spiracles that feed into tubes called tracheae and tracheoles, which go into the body so any cell is only a short distance from air and oxygen can diffuse straight in. The muscles attached to the dragonfly's wings work extremely hard so respire an awful lot in flight and need lots of oxygen. I would guess that that large whole is an extra large spiracle to supply as much oxygen as possible to the flight muscles.
